SECTION 1. FINDINGS. Jackie Roosevelt Robinson, born on January 31, 1919, in Cairo, Georgia, was a standout athlete at the University of California Los Angeles, excelling in multiple sports. In 1947, he broke the color barrier in Major League Baseball by signing with the Brooklyn Dodgers, marking a significant moment in sports history. In 1949, Jackie Robinson won the National League's Most Valuable Player award and in 1962, he was elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame. His achievements in athletics had a profound influence on civil and human rights in America. Jackie Robinson was the first black player in Major League Baseball, signing before the desegregation of the military, civil rights marches, and the Brown v. Board of Education ruling. He quickly gained public admiration for his fortitude, integrity, and athletic ability, surpassing notable figures by the end of 1947. Jackie Robinson, the first black player in Major League Baseball, gained public admiration for his fortitude, integrity, and athletic ability. He ranked behind Bing Crosby in popularity and later held positions at Chock Full O' Nuts and co-founded the Freedom National Bank of Harlem. Robinson influenced political leaders and worked with various organizations to improve the lives of Americans. His life and principles continue to inspire. The Jackie Robinson Foundation preserves his memory by providing educational opportunities for children of low-income families. Robinson's legacy as an athlete, business leader, and citizen has positively influenced civil rights in the United States. The President is authorized to present a gold medal to Jackie Robinson's family in recognition of his contributions to the nation. The Secretary of the Treasury will strike the medal with suitable emblems. Duplicate medals are also authorized. The Secretary is authorized to strike and sell duplicates of the gold medal in bronze to cover costs. The medals are considered national medals. Authorization of appropriations is also granted. SEC. 5. Authorization of Appropriations: Up to $30,000 from the United States Mint Public Enterprise Fund is authorized for the medal cost. Proceeds from bronze medal sales will go to the Fund.

SEC. 6. Sense of Congress. The Sense of Congress is that a national day should be designated to recognize Jackie Robinson's accomplishments, with the President issuing a proclamation for its observance. The congressional gold medal is to be awarded posthumously to Jackie Robinson for his contributions to the Nation. Congress also suggests a national day in his honor.
